lymphatic_tissues: The patient was diagnosed with WAS (Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome) which involves abnormalities in general lymphatic tissues due to a large deletion in exon 1 to 11 of the WAS gene.

Mutation analysis of the UROS gene performed
DNA of exons 2â10 including splicing junctions amplified by PCR and then sequenced
Single missense mutation found leading to amino acid change from valine at position 3 to phenylalanine (fig. 2)
Patient was homozygous for this mutation
UROS genes of parents analyzed, shown to be heterozygote carriers of the mutation
Brother had died of a disease similar to hers in terms of symptoms and abnormalities suggesting he had the same gene mutation
Pedigree analysis spanning three generations showed no other symptomatic patients
Genotype-phenotype relationship confirmed by constructing pET-duet vector carrying mutated cDNA of UROS and transforming it into an Escherichia coli BL21 strain

canals were filled with zinc oxid-eugenol and iodoform paste and restored with resin glass ionomer cement

during the aforementioned treatment, primary mandibular right first molar (#84), primary maxillary right and left first molar (#54,64) and primary mandibular left second molar (#75) showed periapical fistula without evidence of caries or trauma in a short-term
these teeth were extracted
the choice of treatment was to open the pulp chambers and make a dressing with formocresol for other teeth

a fixed space-maintainer was made and cemented with resin modified glass ionomer cement

maternal_health: In 1986, a previously healthy 18-year-old male presented to our hospital with symptoms such as fever, headache and vomiting.
Meningism was noted on examination but no focal neurological signs.
Lumbar puncture revealed slight elevation of protein in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) but no increased cell count.
Right-sided weakness developed over the next few days.
Electroencephalogram demonstrated left parieto-occipital focal slowing.
T1/T2-weighted brain magnetic resonance imaging showed an inflammatory process in the left occipital area.

neurological: Previously healthy male presented with fever, headache, vomiting
Meningism noted on examination but no focal neurological signs
Slight elevation of protein in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) but no increased cell count
Right-sided weakness developed over the next few days
Electroencephalogram demonstrated left parieto-occipital focal slowing
T1/T2-weighted brain magnetic resonance imaging reported to be in keeping with an inflammatory process in the left occipital area
Generalized tonic-clonic seizures ensued
Diagnosed with viral encephalitis, although no causative agent was found
Seizures treated with carbamazepine
Progressive deterioration of functional status
Diagnosed with diabetes mellitus requiring insulin
CT scan of the brain showed diffuse cerebral atrophy, bilateral basal ganglia calcification and a left parieto-occipital hypodensity likely representing a previous stroke-like event
Mitochondrial encephalopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS) was deemed a likely explanation for multi-systemic disease

Mild dysmorphic features including high and arched eyebrows, a hairy forehead, triangular face, slight upslant of palpebral fissures, down turned corners of the mouth, mild hypoplastic alae nasi, prominent pointed chin, deep incisura between tragus and antitragus providing a clear view into the external meatus.

neonatal_health.condition: Testes not palpable in the scrotum
neonatal_health.description: Testes were not palpable in the scrotum.
Required mechanical ventilation and surfactant treatment for respiratory distress syndrome.
Developed hypotension requiring fluid boluses, inotropic support, and antibiotics.
Developed a progressive lactate acidosis with extremely high plasma lactate: 19.1 mmol/L and high pyruvate: 269 Î¼ mol/L. The L/P (lactate/pyruvate) ratio was 71, which is strongly increased.
Increased serum lactate level consistent with primary lactic acidosis caused by a disorder of the pyruvate metabolism or a mitochondrial respiratory chain defect.
Characterized by increased serum lactate, psychomotor delay, hypotonia, failure to thrive, swallowing difficulty, and muscle wasting.

QF PCR and CytoScan HD Array performed showing small de novo duplication on chromosome 11 including exon 1 of the CNTN5 gene
Maternal serum infection testing (TORCHES) was normal
Postnatal cardiac ultrasound confirmed presence of a small VSD
Cranial ultrasound on first postnatal day showed bilateral peri- and intraventricular hemorrhages with dilatation of ventricles, periventricular pseudocysts, and confirmed cerebellar atrophy
DNA analysis of the PDHA1 gene showed no pathogenic mutations
Next-generation sequencing using Illumina MiSeq platform excluded large deletions, point mutations, and small insertions/deletions in mitochondrial DNA derived from blood
Whole exome sequencing performed using Agilent SureSelectXT exome enrichment kit version 4
Sequencing was carried out by an Illumina HiSeq2000 with a 2 Ã 100 bp paired-end recipe
Basecalling and demultiplexing done using bcl2fastq 1.8.4.
Reads aligned onto the human reference genome (hg19) using BWA 0.5.9.
Duplicates marked using PICARD software suite 1.77
Variants called using GATK 2.1-8
Annotations added using an in-house build annotation database according to UCSC RefGene track, dbSNP137, and the dbNSFP (v2.0)
Targeted exome analyses of a panel of 447 nuclear genes performed containing known mitochondrial disease genes and functionally or clinically related genes
Two heterozygous mutations in the FBXL4 gene detected: c.292C>T (p.(Arg98*)) and c.1303C>T (p.(Arg435*))
Both are nonsense mutations resulting in a premature stop codon at position p.98 and p.435 of the FBXL4 protein, respectively

Magnetic resonance imaging revealed localized homogenous hyper intense signals with fusiform swellings of tendoachilles. neurological: The patient was diagnosed with 21-hydroxylase deficiency at birth.
He had been taking oral steroid (hydrocortisone) replacement therapy since then.
Intravenous hydrocortisone treatment was initiated due to the symptoms.
Electroencephalography showed focal epileptic activity.
Routine brain MRI was performed.
Diffusion weighted images (DWI) and susceptibility weighted images (SWI) were also obtained.

T2-weighted and fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) images revealed increased signal intensities in the bilateral frontal and parietooccipital cortical-subcortical regions and a hyperintense lesion in the splenium of the corpus callosum.
Effacement of sulcal spaces was detected compatible with cerebral edema.
Hyperintense cortical-subcortical signals and the lesion in the corpus callosum were hyperintense on DWI with reduced apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) maps.
There were no signal changes suggesting microhemorrhages on SWI.
MRI findings were consistent with cytotoxic cerebral edema in bilateral frontal and parieto-occiptal cortical-subcortical regions due to hypoxia and hypoglisemia.

RESP_tests_image_exam: Routine brain MRI was performed
Diffusion weighted images (DWI) and susceptibility weighted images (SWI) were also obtained to detect ischemia and hemorrhage

T2-weighted and fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) images revealed increased signal intensities in the bilateral frontal and parietooccipital cortical-subcortical regions and a hyperintense lesion in the splenium of the corpus callosum
Effacement of sulcal spaces was detected compatible with cerebral edema
Hyperintense cortical-subcortical signals and the lesion in the corpus callosum were hyperintense on DWI with reduced apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) maps
There were no signal changes suggesting microhemorrhages on SWI
MRI findings were consistent with cytotoxic cerebral edema in bilateral frontal and parieto-occiptal cortical-subcortical regions due to hypoxia and hypoglisemia
DWI and FLAIR images on day 20 indicated partial resolution of the high intensity lesions. Hyperintense signal changes gradually decreased and completely disappeared in frontal lobes
However, ventricular dilatation, mild cerebral cortical atrophy, T2 and FLAIR hyperintense signal changes in bilateral occipital lobes were detected on the last MRI
SWI was normal, and DWI showed restricted diffusion in bilateral occipital lobes

lymphatic_tissues: The patient had previously undergone T7âT9 laminectomy due to thoracic myelopathy at another hospital at the age of 24, after which her myelopathic symptoms subsided for 7 years. At the age of 34, she underwent a second posterior decompression surgery (T4âT9) for gait disturbance due to thoracic myelopathy after a diagnosis of OPLL and OYL, which resulted in improvement of her symptoms.
bone_marrow: The patient had previously undergone T7âT9 laminectomy due to thoracic myelopathy at another hospital at the age of 24, after which her myelopathic symptoms subsided for 7 years. At the age of 34, she underwent a second posterior decompression surgery (T4âT9) for gait disturbance due to thoracic myelopathy after a diagnosis of OPLL and OYL, which resulted in improvement of her symptoms.
immune_cells: Neurologic examination revealed decreased light touch and pinprick sensation, and motor weakness (3/5 strength) in the distal upper extremities. The grip power was 6 kg in both hands. Tendon reflexes were equivocal with indifferent Babinski sign bilaterally.
Lymphatic_tests_image_exam: Plain radiograph showed marked kyphosis of the thoracic spine (T1âT12 angle; 94Â°) ( Fig. 1 ). Computed tomography demonstrated ankylosis of the whole spine below the C2 vertebra with extensive ossification of the paraspinal ligaments ( Fig. 2 A, B). In contrast, decreased but preserved mobility (9Â° on flexion and extension) was noted at the craniovertebral junction (CVJ). No overt radiographic instability was found in the atlantoaxial region, with an atlantodental interval of 1 mm. In addition, there was ossification at the rim of the occipital bone, and OPLL at the C1 level. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed spinal cord compression at the levels of both the occipital bone and C1 ( Fig. 3 ).

GI_tests_image_exam.description: Computed tomography (CT) revealed a hypodense lesion within the left temporal lobe involving gray matter and white matter.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) demonstrated left temporal lobe diffusion signal abnormality and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) hyperintensity predominantly involving the cortex, with cortical and leptomeningeal contrast enhancement.
The apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) map showed preserved, isointense signal in the temporal cortex.
Normal patent vessels without stenosis were seen on MR angiogram.
Lumbar puncture ruled out infection but was significant for elevated lactate to 5.1 mmol/L.
Serum lactate was elevated to 4.6 mmol/L.

Positron emission tomography (PET) showed no evidence of malignancy but demonstrated reduced metabolic activity in the regions of signal abnormality with adjacent metabolic hyperactivity involving the left superior parietal and medial occipital lobes in a gyriform distribution.

MRI demonstrated partial resolution of the left temporal lobe lesion, and new cortical diffusion weighted imaging abnormality in the left temporal and occipital lobes with corresponding FLAIR hyperintensity.
Subsequent MRI showed extension of the occipital lesion to involve more of the parietal and occipital lobes.
MR spectroscopy showed elevated lactate peak at 1.3 ppm diffusely throughout the brain.

Normal ADC signal and postcontrast leptomeningeal enhancement were similarly seen in these regions.

Positron emission tomography (PET) showed no evidence of malignancy but demonstrated reduced metabolic activity in the regions of signal abnormality with adjacent metabolic hyperactivity involving the left superior parietal and medial occipital lobes in a gyriform distribution.

neonatal_health.description: The infant presented with a sex development disorder.
The infant had hyponatremia, characterized by low sodium levels in the blood.
The infant exhibited a decreased level of cortisol, a hormone involved in stress response and metabolism.
The infant had an elevated ACTH level, indicating overproduction of this hormone which stimulates the adrenal glands to produce cortisol.
Despite having a 46, XY karyotype, indicative of male genetics, the infant presented with female genitalia.

genital: Testicular adrenal rest tumor (TART) is one of the possible causes of male infertility
Concomitant congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)
The patient was seen to have obesity (height: 165 cm; weight: 79 kg; Body Mass Index: 29.0 kg/mÂ²).
The laboratory tests revealed an extremely high level of ACTH (316.4 pg/mL) and a relatively low level of cortisol (6.8 Î¼g/dL).

Although the patient did not have any family history of CAH, the CT findings regarding the adrenal glands, unbalanced pituitaryâadrenal hormones, and high level of serum 17-OHP (62.7 ng/mL) indicated the possibility of CAH.
The differential diagnosis was made before a testicular examination.
At the physical examination, both testes had become slightly atrophied (right: 14 mL; left: 12 mL) (performed with a Prader orchidmeter).
No induration was palpated.

The semen analysis showed azoospermia.

maternal_health: 21-year-old male experienced visual loss after diving
Bilateral subretinal hemorrhages and angioid streaks identified
Linear vertical break formation in Bruchâs membrane observed
Angioid streaks, peau dâorange, and comet tails noted
Preliminary diagnosis of PXE made based on symptoms

neurological: Twenty years later, in April 2009, he presented again because of recent visual loss in the left eye.
Neuro_Tests_Imaging_Exam: Ocular examination was performed the same day
Clinical examination, FA, and OCT revealed active choroidal neovascularisation nasal to the fovea with leakage and edema.
One month after a first intravitreal injection of bevacizumab, the edema had resolved and vision improved.
During the following months a total of 8 injections of bevacizumab were administred on the LE
Despite this treatment growth of the choroidal neovascularization (CNV) was observed with further deterioration of vision.
In January 2010, active CNV was also identified in the right eye and treatment with bevacizumab intravitreal injections was initiated.

maternal_health: Patient 1 was diagnosed with PXE at 18 years of age
Duplex scan disclosed bilateral calcified short stenosis (>70%) of the superficial femoral arteries (SFAs)
Primary angioplasty with stenting of the right SFA was performed
Four weeks later, intermittent claudication recurred and duplex scanning disclosed bilateral thrombosis of the stented SFAs
Patient 2 was diagnosed with PXE at 20 years of age
Duplex scans disclosed significant stenosis (>70%) of the left SFA
Angioplasty of the left SFA with a nitinol stent (LifeStent; Bard) was performed after failure of medical treatment
One day later, duplex scanning confirmed reocclusion (ABI, 0.46) of the stented SFA
Patient 3 was diagnosed with PXE at 8 years of age
At 38 years, the patient underwent her first angioplasty with stenting for stenosis of the right SFA
Nine years later, claudication worsened on the left leg and angioplasty of the SFA was performed
Twelve months later, in-stent stenosis of the left SFA was found, again treated by angioplasty
Patient 4 was diagnosed with PXE at 41 years of age
At 44 years, he complained of severe claudication and duplex scans showed severe stenosis of both SFAs
Bilateral angioplasty with stenting (S.M.A.R.T. stent; Cordis) was performed

maternal_health: A 20-year-old male presented with a gradually increasing swelling of the left testis for 1 year duration
Diagnosed to have CAH at the age of 1 year but had defaulted treatment at the age of 4 years
Genital examination revealed a large hard indurated swelling of both epididymes more prominent on the left side
Left testis was ill-defined with an approximate diameter of 3.5 cm
Ultrasonography showed bilateral enlargement of the testes and epididymes
Bilateral grade-II varicocele
Seminal fluid analysis showed azoospermia
A biopsy of the right epididymis was performed
Histopathological analysis revealed nodules of cells with intervening dense fibrous septae
The nodules comprised nests and cords of polygonal Leydig cells
Cell borders were distinct and a lymphoid infiltrate was present in the stroma
Testicular tissue comprised of seminiferous tubules with thickened basement membranes
Residual testicular tissue showed predominantly germ cell aplasia with occasional tubules containing spermatogonia
Most seminiferous tubules contained only Sertoli cells
Spermatocytes, spermatids and spermatozoa were absent
Collections of Leydig cells were noted between the seminiferous tubules
Intratubular germ cell neoplasia or malignancy was absent
The histopathological analysis was more in favour of TART rather than Leydig cell neoplasm
A course of prednisolone was started and there was good response
In 6 weeks, there was marked reduction in the sizes of testes with minimal induration

neurological: Cystinosis results from a functional defect in the lysosomal-membrane exporter protein, cystinosin (CTNS), thereby resulting in failure of cystine efflux from cell lysosomes.
Nephropathic cystinosis (NC) is often diagnosed in infancy due to the development of severe renal Fanconi syndrome with failure to thrive. Chronic electrolyte replacement is essential.
Cystine accumulation is measured in leukocytes with a cystine level < 1 nmol 1/2 cystine per milligram cell protein categorized as being consistent with optimal cystine depletion.
Cysteamine bitartrate is the only Food and Drug Administrationâapproved therapy for cystinosis and is available in immediate and delayed release formulations.
In NC, the 57-kb deletion has been associated with transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1) gene functional impairment.

Long-term extra renal manifestations of NC are frequently observed and include cognitive impairment and/or delays, altered skin and/or heat sensations, abnormal temperature regulation, heat intolerance, reduced sweating, and myopathy, the latter of which may eventually contribute to respiratory failure, all suggestive of autonomic nervous system dysfunction pertinent to thermoregulation.
cognitive: Both twins frequently described issues with heat intolerance and photophobia secondary to corneal cystine crystal deposition, but they demonstrated consistently normal clinical neurological examination findings.

We decided to complete further testing of the twins to evaluate heat intolerance and possible associated autonomic dysfunction as opposed to what may simply be avoidance of light exposure on sunny days.
Neuro_Tests_Imaging_Exam: Table 1 includes clinical and medication data on the patients at the time of autonomic testing.
Twin 2 exhibited a diastolic blood pressure (DBP) that exceeded the threshold for sex and height and had DBP readings 20% higher than those of twin 1.

RESP_tests_image_exam: Noninvasive imaging with MPM and OCT was performed to visualize any irregularities in dermal elastin and/or calcium deposits.
We imaged an area of lax skin on the right axilla with dynamic OCT (VivoSight Dx, Michelson Diagnostics Ltd, London, UK) and MPM tomography (MPTflex, JenLab GmbH, Jena, Germany).
OCT imaging of the lax axilla skin displayed large areas of hyporeflective, homogeneous areas of attenuation, or signal loss, in the mid dermis
The depth of the PXE image exhibits relative superficial attenuation of 50% at 0.3 mm and near complete attenuation at a depth of about 0.53 mm
The observed changes may be associated with the noted abundance of elastin at and above this level on histology

Fig 3 OCT cross-section of PXE shows homogenous areas of premature signal loss (yellow, dotted circle) with 50% of total attenuation at 0.3 mm below the skin surface and near-complete attenuation at about 0.53 mm

skeletal: At 19.42 gestational weeks (GWs), ultrasound revealed genitalia that were female-appearing but ambiguous or atypical.
A karyotype indicated the fetus was 46,XX with no chromosomal abnormalities.

CYP21A2 gene testing of DNA from amniotic fluid showed compound heterozygosity for an R356W mutation on one allele and a 30-kb deletion on the other allele, confirming a prenatal diagnosis of CAH due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
Parental genetic testing confirmed the fetal genotype.

At 29.14 GW, high-resolution prenatal ultrasound (General Electric, 5-9 MHz transducer) was performed and three serial 2D measurements of the biparietal diameter (71.1 mm; 20th percentile) of the fetus and two serial 2D measurements of the head circumference (258.1 mm; 3rd percentile) were averaged and compared with standard references using the Hadlock growth curves.

At 30.57 GW, fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI; Philips 1.5T) was performed to better evaluate clinically for other abnormalities as MRI can provide information regarding certain conditions like white matter abnormalities and temporal lobe atrophy that cannot be obtained by ultrasound alone.
2-D and 3-D MRI measurements of fetal brain structures were computed (Figure 1) and shown in Table 1.
Significant deficits were noted for skull biparietal diameter and occipitofrontal diameter versus age-matched controls (Figure 2).
Absolute biparietal diameter measurements were similar for ultrasound and MRI.
3-D measurements were obtained of the extra-axial cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) volume, supratentorial volume, cerebellar volume, cortical plate volume, and total lateral ventricles volume (Figure 3).
Total intracranial volume and deep gray matter volume, but not developing white matter, showed deficits versus controls (Table 1).
A postnatal follow-up MRI of the patient on day 10 of life showed a total brain volume (300.82 cmÂ³) that was below the 5th percentile for age-matched, healthy infants.

The neonate had an elevated serum 17-OHP of 11,500 ng/dL (normal range for term newborns within 12 h of birth: â¤460 ng/dL), androstenedione 4917 ng/dL (normal range not established for newborns; normal range for infants: 6â78 ng/dL), and testosterone 279 ng/dL (normal range of females 1â10 days old: â¤24 ng/dL).

neurological: The patient developed an attack of generalized tonic-clonic seizure associated with low-grade fever.
On examination, the patient was confused in post-ictal state.

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis
The patient began to become agitated and developed generalized muscle pain despite proper correction of resistant hyponatremia with hypertonic saline 3%.

Within the next few days, she developed weakness in both lower limbs, right more than left, which was rapidly progressing to involve upper limbs associated with trunk muscle affection till the patient became quadriplegic.

Electrophysiological studies revealed evidence of purely motor axonal polyneuropathy affecting upper and lower limbs with bilateral facial axonal neuropathy (prolonged first time (F) wave latencies with reduced amplitude of compound motor action potentials).
The CSF examination showed cytoalbuminous dissociation.

skeletal: A cauliflower-like mass at the beginning of the ascending colon was found during a colonoscopy.
Ascending colon cancer with intussusception was identified through abdominal contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT).
During surgery, it was observed that there were two inferior mesenteric arteries (ICAs) derived from the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), with the ileocolic vein (ICV) crossing anterior to the SMA.
The right colic artery (RCA) originated from the front of the SMA.
The proximal end of the SMA was located on the left side of the superior mesenteric vein (SMV), but the distal end of the SMA was always located on the right side of the SMV.

RESP_tests_image_exam: Physical examination revealed ataxia, dysarthria, and spastic paraparesis with pyramidal signs more prominent on the right lower extremity.

Eye examination and other neurological tests were performed because of his symptoms such as visual impairment, peripheral neuropathy, hallucinations, depression, and delusion and yielded negative results.
There was no sign of palpable xanthoma in any of his tendons even in Achilles tendon.

In the examination of his right hand, the fourth and fifth interphalangeal joints were flexed, and the third and fifth metacarpophalangeal joints were extended, which was found to be the result of presence of small xanthoma in the tendons of the right hand (Figure 1).
Electromyography and nerve conduction velocity (EMG/NCV) revealed no evidence of myopathy or neuropathy, and the motor and sensory conduction velocities were normal.
Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) demonstrated diffuse and focal cerebral and cerebellar white matter abnormalities (Figure 2).

The genetic study was performed by the next-generation sequencing (NGS) method, and the results were confirmed by the Sanger sequencing method. The apparent homozygous variants in the NM_000784.4(CYP27A1): c.803G>A (p.Trp268*) and NM_032382.5(COG8) : c.1073G>A (p.Arg358Gln) in the CYP27A1 and COG8 genes were found which are pathogenic based on American College of Medical Genetics (ACMG) classification.

maternal_health: 28-year-old Mexican woman experiencing recurring episodes of intense abdominal pain
Weakness in upper and lower extremities
Uncontrollable vomiting
Insomnia since the age of 17
Symptoms requiring frequent visits to emergency department
Persisted despite normal biochemical tests, imaging tests, and surgery for suspected acute appendicitis
Elevated urine PBG confirmed diagnosis of AIP (Autoimmune Idiopathic Hepatitis) after nearly 3 years
Initiated treatment with hematin derivatives resulting in partial improvement
Progressively severe crises accompanied by paralysis and kidney injury
Elevated urine PBG detected during asymptomatic periods
First cousin diagnosed with AIP having similar clinical presentation
Molecular genetic study conducted revealing heterozygous state mutation c.457C > T (p.Q153) in the HMBS gene
Enrolled in a clinical trial for Givosiran, an RNA interference therapeutic targeting ALAS1 mRNA
Notable response to treatment and continued it even after the trial
Symptoms have been sporadic over years without requiring hospitalization

Neuro_Tests_Imaging_Exam: Normal biochemical tests
Abdominal surgery for suspected acute appendicitis
Molecular genetic study conducted at a reference center in Belgium to identify the mutation causing AIP
Direct sequencing using capillary electrophoresis and the BigDye technology (Applied Biosystems)
Data alignment and comparison with the wildtype sequence (NM_000190.3) performed using the GenBank Database

Diagnosis of Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone secretion (SIADH)
